poem:
Title: Congo's Prodigious Prodigy

In the heart of Congo, Baloji's essence seethes,
From Brussels' flavors arose a laurel wreath.
Honored at Cannes, every film-reel breath,
A conjurer of tales—no grisly death.

Chameleon of tones, weaving threads,
Melodies and magic, where his discourse treads.
Get Out, it's said, found resemblance keen,
Yet in Baloji's work, more depth is seen.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Omen (Augure) review – Baloji offers secrets and sorcery in Congolese homecoming Congolese-born rapper, musician and film-maker Baloji (né Serge Baloji Tshiani) was a prizewinner at Cannes last year with this feature directing debut: a dynamic, teemingly populated, multistranded and tonally elusive picture which I initially thought would benefit from comparisons with Jordan Peele’s horror classic Get Out. In fact, it’s more complicated than that. Koffi (Marc Zinga) is a Congolese man living in Belgium". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
